title: Working backwards to implement a preferred future
subtitle: Backcasting invites us to start strategic conversations from a speculative future, by identifying the key differences between that future and today.

title: Find out how your users feel by drawing the body inside out
subtitle: A body map is composed of a simple outline of a human figure. After experiencing an interaction or situation, participants are invited to visually document their bodily experience by drawing and writing on the silhouette.

title: Harnessing creativity to reveal hidden needs
subtitle: Context mapping belongs to the family of generative research techniques in which participants make artefacts that represent their experiences and talk about these, which enables them to reflect more deeply on their lives.

title: Building a strong design team by recognising and valuing attributes
subtitle: The design team cards method helps team members reflect on their own attributes, using a set of predefined ‘roles’ to identify how they might best contribute.

title: Making the precedents and consequences of our designs visible
subtitle: Design timescapes visualise historical and future influences in an organised way, allowing us to better understand how design concepts, products and projects came into being and what the consequences of their realisation are for broader society.

title: Making visible the invisible to better understand your user and their experiences
subtitle: Empathy mapping is a visual method that can support the understanding and interpretation of previously collected data by directly representing the experience of an individual person.

title: If we don’t plan the world we want, we have to live with the one we get
subtitle: The impact ripple canvas helps us extrapolate the consequences of a design decision outwards so we can visualise a network of secondary and tertiary actions that might spawn from the – usually well thought out – primary consequences.

title: Cultivating the art of observing a place
subtitle: The local orbits method encourages acknowledgement of the challenges and opportunities specific to the locale within which we are designing, by cultivating our sensory perceptions of a place.

title: Engaging with physical materials to find new ways of doing things
subtitle: Material exploration prompts designers to select and consciously explore materials and to draw on that exploration for ways that the material could be used in a design solution.

title: Breaking a big, messy problem into bite-sized pieces
subtitle: Morphological charts offer a structured way of breaking a big problem down into manageable parts and tackling these one at a time, with the aim of finding the optimum solution.

title: Giving a voice to living things and ecosystems
subtitle: Non-human personas address some limitations of human-centred design methods, by adapting the personas method to give non-human stakeholders a voice in the design process.

title: Encouraging people to interact with temporary installations in public spaces
subtitle: Pop-up installations provide an engaging way of collecting data from people in public spaces by employing a variety of formats, such as ‘pop-up’ events that are located in high pedestrian thoroughfares.

title: Why settle for one future when you can explore four?
subtitle: Scenario-based thinking allows us to generate four possible future scenarios based on local and global drivers, to understand their impact on the success or failure of the products or services we design.

title: Using dystopian and utopian narratives to explore a problem area
subtitle: Speculating preferred futures encourages the consideration, development and communication of new realities and new possibilities, with the aim to lead to new ideas and a deeper understanding of the problem area.

title: Turning a web of external factors into actionable insights
subtitle: The STEP card method can be used individually or as a group during the early stage of a project as a visual way of capturing external factors.

title: Improving a strategy with five key questions
subtitle: The strategy choice cascade uses a collaborative way of thinking about the driving questions in strategy development, using a non-sequential pathway based on five key questions.

title: Visually identifying the components of complex systems
subtitle: Systems maps support systems thinking, which is an approach to understanding how the individual components within a network influence each other. They can be represented in various ways, most of which focus on identifying causal relationships.

title: Visualising values to inform design decisions
subtitle: Our values are fundamental to who we are and guide many of our day-to-day decisions. The values cartouche method offers an approach to identifying and articulating personal values in a visual way.

title: Visualising the relationships between wireframes
subtitle: Wireflow diagrams are a quick way to visualise how individual screen designs ‘connect’ to each other. The wireflow method uses elements from wireframes and flowcharts, bringing both of these communication tools together.

title: Unlocking creative thinking by encouraging terrible ideas
subtitle: Giving people the permission to come up with their worst possible ideas creates a playful, safe environment and helps to get a brainstorming session off to a good start.
